body:
> The handler should clean up the file after the request is served.

Maybe, maybe not.  What if the request submits the temporary file to a queue to be asynchronously processed?  This is very common, after uploading an image, you want to do some processing on it (eg adjusting the size/resolution), but you don't want to keep the user waiting, so the request returns immediately.  If we cleaned up after the request, the file would disappear before any processing could be done on it.

There's also no way to implement this safely now - the body parser has no way to do anything after a request is processed.

I think the best thing to do here is to document that users need to clean it up themselves.

It's called TemporaryFile for a reason -- isn't that enough of a warning
that if you want to keep it you should move it?

On Mon, Feb 9, 2015 at 8:04 PM, James Roper notifications@github.com
wrote:

> The handler should clean up the file after the request is served.
> 
> Maybe, maybe not. What if the request submits the temporary file to a
> queue to be asynchronously processed? This is very common, after uploading
> an image, you want to do some processing on it (eg adjusting the
> size/resolution), but you don't want to keep the user waiting, so the
> request returns immediately. If we cleaned up after the request, the file
> would disappear before any processing could be done on it.
> 
> There's also no way to implement this safely now - the body parser has no
> way to do anything after a request is processed.
> 
> I think the best thing to do here is to document that users need to clean
> it up themselves.
> 
> ## 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/playframework/playframework/issues/3913#issuecomment-73624992
> .

if user call moveTo, can we make it a real moveTo which means do not keep original temp File and move the file to the destination file?

another questions is it safe for end user to call image.ref.file.delete() themselves to clean up the temp file,   any impact?

Yes, `moveTo` is doing a `copy` then `delete` instead of a real move, but only if `File.renameTo` fails (see javadocs for more information about why it may fail). But I think we can remove [this deprecated API](https://github.com/marcospereira/playframework/blob/master/framework/src/play/src/main/scala/play/api/libs/Files.scala#L67-L184) and just use `java.nio.file.Files`. Any reason to keep this deprecated API around?
Good, thank you @jroper. I will submit a PR doing a real `moveTo` and also removing these APIs.

issue.title: Replaces deprecated APIs with Java NIO

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Also, TemporaryFile now has a real moveTo method which uses Java NIO to do the moving, instead of
a copy->delete of the file being moved.

This fixes #3913.

issue.title: Temporary files are not cleaned up on app shutdown

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
If you upload a file via a `"multipart/form-data"` form and don't consume (e.g. by moving it) or delete the uploaded file within the action method, the temporary files does not get deleted after the action method finishes. Instead the deletion of the file is left to the garbage collector. Also see #3913 for more explanation.
I can confirm this is working.

However when shuting down the app (e.g. via CTRL+C or `kill` in prod mode) temporary files still remain in my `/tmp` folder, they don't get deleted.
I consider this a bug.

issue.title: Temporary files are not deleted if TemporaryFile objects are not garbage collected

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Temporary files are not deleted from disk unless the corresponding TemporaryFile objects are garbage collected. When garbage collection is not run in a timely manner, the files accumulate on disk and can lead to a denial of service.

The problem is exacerbated for requests that exceed `maxDiskBuffer` as handles to the temporary files are never passed to client code, so the client does not have an opportunity to delete the files.

issue.title: Potential delete of temporary file before it is used

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Play 2.5.10

when using `Action.async(parse.raw)` you get a `RawBuffer` as body.

This internally has a `TemporaryFile` that is unreachable but which will remove the file when it is garbage collected. 

```scala
    /**
     * Delete this file on garbage collection.
     */
    override def finalize() {
      clean()
    }
```

This `RawBuffer` also has a method `asFile()` which returns `backedByTemporaryFile.file`

If you put this file in a queue and want to process it after the request has finished there is a chance that it has been removed by a garbage collection of the no longer referenced TemporaryFile.

It would be better to return the TemporaryFile which has a `moveTo()` after which you become responsible for cleaning up the file.
(preferable this TemporaryFile would not even allow access to its file property)

see #3913 for a related discussion
